rev.diff:
Line 22: Line 22:
While Dropbox functions as a storage service, its focus is on synchronization and sharing. Dropbox synchronization uses [[SSL]] transfers with AES-256 encryption, and it supports revision history, so files deleted from the Dropbox folder may be recovered from any of the synced computers.<ref>{{cite web | title = Dropbox FAQ's, Security and Privacy | publisher = Dropbox | url = https://www.getdropbox.com/faq#security-and-privacy | accessdate = 2008-09-22 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | author = Adam Pash | title = Dropbox Syncs and Backs Up Files Between Computers Instantaneously | publisher = Lifehacker | url = http://lifehacker.com/397778/dropbox-syncs-and-backs-up-files-between-computers-instantaneously | accessdate 2008-09-22 }}</ref> Dropbox's version control also helps users know the history of a file they may be currently working on, enabling more than one person to edit and re-post files without complications of losing its previous form.<ref>{{cite web | author = Jason Snell | title = Throw your stuff in Dropbox | publisher = Macworld | url = http://www.macworld.com/article/138810/2009/02/mwvodcast93.html | accessdate = 2009-02-13}}</ref> There is no limit to file size for files added via the Dropbox application, but files transferred through the web interface are capped at 350 MB. Dropbox uses [[Amazon.com|Amazon's]] [[Amazon S3|S3]] storage system to store the files.
While Dropbox functions as a storage service, its focus is on synchronization and sharing. Dropbox synchronization uses [[SSL]] transfers with AES-256 encryption, and it supports revision history, so files deleted from the Dropbox folder may be recovered from any of the synced computers.<ref>{{cite web | title = Dropbox FAQ's, Security and Privacy | publisher = Dropbox | url = https://www.getdropbox.com/faq#security-and-privacy | accessdate = 2008-09-22 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | author = Adam Pash | title = Dropbox Syncs and Backs Up Files Between Computers Instantaneously | publisher = Lifehacker | url = http://lifehacker.com/397778/dropbox-syncs-and-backs-up-files-between-computers-instantaneously | accessdate 2008-09-22 }}</ref> Dropbox's version control also helps users know the history of a file they may be currently working on, enabling more than one person to edit and re-post files without complications of losing its previous form.<ref>{{cite web | author = Jason Snell | title = Throw your stuff in Dropbox | publisher = Macworld | url = http://www.macworld.com/article/138810/2009/02/mwvodcast93.html | accessdate = 2009-02-13}}</ref> There is no limit to file size for files added via the Dropbox application, but files transferred through the web interface are capped at 350 MB. Dropbox uses [[Amazon.com|Amazon's]] [[Amazon S3|S3]] storage system to store the files.
â
The Dropbox service is similar to companies such as [[Box.net]], [[Mozy]], [[Wuala]] and the now defunct [[Omnidrive]] and [[Xdrive (website)|XDrive]]. The major feature (and limitation) of the Dropbox system is that only files in the Dropbox folder are backed up and synced. The company received seed funding from [[Y Combinator]] and [[Sequoia Capital]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Dropbox: About Us | publisher = Dropbox | url = https://www.getdropbox.com/about | accessdate = 2008-09-22 }}</ref>
+
The Dropbox service is similar to companies such as [[Box.net]], [[Mozy]], [[Wuala]]. The major feature (and limitation) of the Dropbox system is that only files in the Dropbox folder are backed up and synced. The company received seed funding from [[Y Combinator]] and [[Sequoia Capital]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Dropbox: About Us | publisher = Dropbox | url = https://www.getdropbox.com/about | accessdate = 2008-09-22 }}</ref>
